div1.p: Carter writes about his children and other personal matters.

div1.head: Letter fragment from Henry Rose Carter to [Emma Coleman Carter], [18--]
div1.p:
rejoicing on being barefoot & shows his feet with
great pride. Tell Mary he takes almost as much
pride in a - most miserably - stuffed crane (or Egret) - known
as “Guk” (“duck” I suppose) - as Henry did in the stuffed
Mallard duck in San Francisco. He feeds it, talks
to it & smoothes its feathers the wrong way for
hours at a time. He is a ridiculous child, but I ifsup-
pose all children are if one watches them closely.
I was very sorry to hear of Kate Fontaine's death. I
thought a great deal of her & the loss to her poor chil-
dren is well nigh iremediable. What is the matter
with the Beaver Dam House, that Diphtheria &
Typhoid Fever should originate there? Those disea-
ses should be rare in the low countries.

I have just brought the children back from the
wreck of the Burgenseen: it being the 1st, & probably the
last, chance they have to see it. We brought off an
old fashioned hour-glass, the first I have ever seen,
as a memento. Also a red streamer of bunting for
a pennant for Henry & some plaited rope yarn for a mat
for Laura & a buchenswood stool for Ned. So we feel
quite like wreckers & pirates.

I heard from my Fla man & he says nearly half of
the trees set out in Feb. were killed by the freeze & drought
combined- that is a less number than I had feared but
alas is was the budded half that suffered & those are
the most valuable. The older trees were not hurt
This place is not so bad by any means as ship Island
or as last year. It is quiet & isolated but I am
but little, if at all, more isolated than I was at San Fran-
cisco. & while I led a very active life in Cairo. I never saw
anyone save as a matter of business. The climate just
now isn't bad & we are not at present troubled with
any insects save roaches which are in abun-
dance or rather super abundance, & the little “German”
roaches bite. not severely but, bite Eddy so as
to make a sore place. Of course we are going to have
heat. mosquitoes & sand flies- the most pestiferous insects in ex-
istence - & have them in excess: but we don't have them all
the time here & there was little good about S. Island

I can't help congratulating Ed, on his escape from his
Mother in law. I am sure she will not venture a cross
alone & I suppose E. has “influence” enough to be kept W of the
Missouri, until In all seriousness however it is infin-
itely best that no one, however discrete, kind etc, be with them
for 18 months at least.
